Operation 'digitalassetlinks.assetlinks.bulkCheck' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Missing summary entirely. Description lacks clarity about what is returned (CheckResponse objects) and the order guarantee. Added explicit mention of return format and error handling to improve AI agent understanding of the operation's complete behavior.

data.current_description: Send a bundle of statement checks in a single RPC to minimize latency and service load. Statements need not be all for the same source and/or target. We recommend using this method when you need to check more than one statement in a short period of time.
data.summary_suggestion: Check multiple asset link relationships in a single request
data.description_suggestion: Verifies multiple directional relationships between digital assets in a single RPC call to minimize latency and service load. Accepts a batch of statement checks where statements can involve different source and target assets. Returns a list of CheckResponse objects in the same order as the requests, with individual results and any errors for each statement. Useful when checking multiple asset relationships within a short time period.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description lacks clarity about what is returned (CheckResponse objects) and the order guarantee. Added explicit mention of return format and error handling to improve AI agent understanding of the operation's complete behavior.

message: Operation 'digitalassetlinks.assetlinks.check' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details. Missing summary entirely. Description is comprehensive but lacks explicit mention of required input parameters (source, target, relation). Reorganized to lead with parameters and return value for better AI agent clarity on what inputs are needed and what to expect.

data.current_description: Determines whether the specified (directional) relationship exists between the specified source and target assets. The relation describes the intent of the link between the two assets as claimed by the source asset. An example for such relationships is the delegation of privileges or permissions. This command is most often used by infrastructure systems to check preconditions for an action. For example, a client may want to know if it is OK to send a web URL to a particular mobile app instead. The client can check for the relevant asset link from the website to the mobile app to decide if the operation should be allowed. A note about security: if you specify a secure asset as the source, such as an HTTPS website or an Android app, the API will ensure that any statements used to generate the response have been made in a secure way by the owner of that asset. Conversely, if the source asset is an insecure HTTP website (that is, the URL starts with `http://` instead of `https://`), the API cannot verify its statements securely, and it is not possible to ensure that the website's statements have not been altered by a third party. For more information, see the [Digital Asset Links technical design specification](https://github.com/google/digitalassetlinks/blob/master/well-known/details.md).
data.summary_suggestion: Verify a directional relationship between two digital assets
data.description_suggestion: Determines whether a specified directional relationship exists between source and target assets. The relation represents the intent of the link as claimed by the source asset (e.g., delegation of privileges). Requires source asset, target asset, and relation type as parameters. Returns a CheckResponse indicating whether the relationship exists and any supporting statements. Security note: For secure sources (HTTPS websites, Android apps), statements are verified as made by the asset owner. For insecure HTTP sources, statement verification cannot be guaranteed. Commonly used by infrastructure systems to validate preconditions before allowing operations between assets.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description is comprehensive but lacks explicit mention of required input parameters (source, target, relation). Reorganized to lead with parameters and return value for better AI agent clarity on what inputs are needed and what to expect.

message: Operation 'digitalassetlinks.statements.list' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Missing summary entirely. Description lacks explicit mention of required parameters and return type (ListResponse with Statement objects). Reorganized to clearly state inputs, outputs, and use cases upfront for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description: Retrieves a list of all statements from a given source that match the specified target and statement string. The API guarantees that all statements with secure source assets, such as HTTPS websites or Android apps, have been made in a secure way by the owner of those assets, as described in the [Digital Asset Links technical design specification](https://github.com/google/digitalassetlinks/blob/master/well-known/details.md). Specifically, you should consider that for insecure websites (that is, where the URL starts with `http://` instead of `https://`), this guarantee cannot be made. The `List` command is most useful in cases where the API client wants to know all the ways in which two assets are related, or enumerate all the relationships from a particular source asset. Example: a feature that helps users navigate to related items. When a mobile app is running on a device, the feature would make it easy to navigate to the corresponding web site or Google+ profile.
data.summary_suggestion: List all verified statements between source and target assets
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves all statements from a specified source asset that match the given target asset and statement relation type. Returns a ListResponse containing a list of Statement objects representing all verified relationships. Requires source asset, target asset, and relation type as parameters. Security guarantee: Statements from secure sources (HTTPS websites, Android apps) are verified as made by the asset owner. Statements from insecure HTTP sources cannot be verified. Useful for discovering all relationship types between two assets or enumerating all relationships from a particular source asset, such as helping users navigate to related web properties or profiles.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description lacks explicit mention of required parameters and return type (ListResponse with Statement objects). Reorganized to clearly state inputs, outputs, and use cases upfront for better AI agent interpretability.

The `List` command is most useful in cases where the API client wants to know all the ways in which two assets are related, or enumerate all the relationships from a particular source asset. Example: a feature that helps users navigate to related items. When a mobile app is running on a device, the feature would make it easy to navigate to the corresponding web site or Google+ profile.
data.summary_suggestion: List all verified statements between source and target assets
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves all statements from a specified source asset that match the given target asset and statement relation type. Returns a ListResponse containing a list of Statement objects representing all verified relationships. Requires source asset, target asset, and relation type as parameters. Security guarantee: Statements from secure sources (HTTPS websites, Android apps) are verified as made by the asset owner. Statements from insecure HTTP sources cannot be verified. Useful for discovering all relationship types between two assets or enumerating all relationships from a particular source asset, such as helping users navigate to related web properties or profiles.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description lacks explicit mention of required parameters and return type (ListResponse with Statement objects). Reorganized to clearly state inputs, outputs, and use cases upfront for better AI agent interpretability.

message: Semantic analysis completed: 3 operations analyzed, 3 quality issues found
